review_title: Decent benefits, friendly company, poor staffing
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Newark, OH
pros: The benefits are very good for a hospital system without a nursing union. Staff is all very friendly, creating a great atmosphere to work in.
cons: Staffing shortages can create potentially unsafe patient ratios of 6+ per nurse. Employees strongly advised to report that they took a 30 minute lunch, even if this was not possible, and often is not possible. Strongly vindictive attendance points system even punishes getting injured on the job, and points are now rarely removed for picking up extra shifts. Department transfers can be blocked or put on hold by your current department's manager.

pros: Decent pay, free uniforms, other perks

job_title: Physician Center Clerk in Newark, OH
pros:
This is a company that promotes success and general care for the community. I worked at LMH for almost 2 years and I can not wait to return someday (I left to continue my education). The initial orientation process is great, HR does a wonderful job at welcoming new employees to the company. The CEO, Rob Montagnese does an exceptional job at acknowledging and rewarding his employees. In my 2 years at Licking, I received a number of generous bonuses and 2 pay raises (no complaints in that area). Lastly, the insurance package is terrific, especially if you have a large family. I am proud to say that I was a former employee at LMH and would recommend this company to friends and family. 

Side note: The staff at Licking Memorial Hospital was responsible for saving my mother's life, 2 times. I can not thank them enough for what they did for my family and I. Thank you, LMH.
cons: The only complaint I would have pertains to the uniforms. The clerical uniforms were uncomfortable, outdated, EXPENSIVE, and did not come in petite sizes.

pros: The patients and the other employees.
cons: Everything else. It was one of the worst employment experiences of my life. Avoid working there if at all possible. It is a revolving door culture of mistrust and abuse. They live by the "there is someone else to take your job if you don't want it" mentality. The ratios are insanely out of whack. Senior leaders have no clue what they are doing. If you start a job here prepare to start looking for another job within a few months. The senior leadership functions like a feudal clan. They are a bunch of back biting ignorant country bumpkins that have a very high opinion of themselves.

pros: Good experience for healthcare careers.
cons: CONSTANT drama. You can't go a day without someone trying to involve you in something. Nurses literally SCREAMING at techs over minor issues or nothing at all pretty frequently and management has nothing to say about it. Cussing and screaming wouldn't be accepted elsewhere. Poor professional standards and toxicity around every unit. Pay was less than columbus area hospitals for more work too.

pros: It's the only health care system locally perhaps
cons:
During one of the meetings, the CEO did not know the difference between family medicine and internal medicine, implied pediatric call coverage for an internist.  That's a red flag when the firm is supposed to have an "open minded and forward thinking CEO"?

The office manager did not know the term CME (continuing medical education) credits after been there for years?  Red flag again.

Lack of a dyad system where one MD in each level of administration is matched with an administrator to improve clinical operations.  More like a close-minded organization.

pros: If you can get past that this place wants you at work even if you are severly ill and don't care that you can potentially spread infection to patients and Co-workers then sure fantastic place to work.
cons: I was let go because I called off twice within my first thirty days of employment even though I had health issues and I had a doctor's word and signature from a doctor employed by this organization! When you are coughing and throwing up you do not need to be anywhere near food service which is where I was. how can an organization condone that employees should come to work sick then handle and prepare food for patients that are already there with health problems,  absolutely horrid this hospital shouldn't even be permitted to run horrible business and health practices. Managers and supervisors will take the first chance they can to undermine you and make you look bad when something goes wrong,  human resources are worse than debt sharks I sent in a letter of appeal to appeal my termination because I felt it was best that I shouldn't spread infection within the hospital especially handling food and their response letter was that I should have come to work that that was not an excuse to call off of work so clearly this hospitals priorities are completly about money instead of saving and improving lives. This hospital got an award for one of the best places to work in the US I have a good feeling that some money was thrown around under the table to obtain this award because any business that legitimately gets this award doesn't do that to their employees.
